@Halsted_19 It‚Äôs actually doesn‚Äôt really change the epigenetic clock except for a couple of instances‚Ä¶. I‚Äôd be very curious to see which cells exactly get reprogrammed ‚Ä¶
@Halsted_19 They are talking about skin. After inducing an injury they monitor how well the wound heals and they see more cells dividing and less fibrosis in animals that underwent reprogramming.

Lovely to see an improved wound healing phenotype after partial reprogramming. Means that reprogramming in vivo actually does something useful to a mouse, not just causes a bunch of "good" molecular changes (not that it's not insignificant by itself). Congrats to the authors!

Holy shit! A centimeter-long bacterium that is visible with a naked eye! 
It has very peculiar internal organization with DNA depots and protein synthesis in membrane-bound organelles and other "weird" features. 
We have yet so much to learn from nature..

By studying what the tapeworm secretes (or any other  activities that it does) we can figure out what are these fabulous levers that can be pulled to change the ants' biology so dramatically. 

I don't know about you, but I'm completely fascinated by stories like this one
Now the most interesting thing, of course, is that nature evolved the tapeworms to somehow casually extend the host's lifespan 3-fold.

The infected ants become lazy and that puts a lot of stress on the rest of the workers, which makes the overall colony not function as well. And then when the bird attacks - it's the clueless infected ants that get eaten for the worm to procreate.

Would you make a deal with a ... parasite if it gave you 3X lifespan in a youthful body, nice smell and everyone around you wanting to pamper you? 

That's the story of the Temnothorax ants. A tapeworm gives them youth, but there's a catch (as always). 
https://t.co/qenDMXWik2
